post.title: Powerlines across massive lake show curvature of Earth

body: I'd tend to agree, they look way too close together...so much so that the slack in the lines is actually enough for a hurricane to get the lines caught on the tops of the towers.
body_html: I'd tend to agree, they look way too close together...so much so that the slack in the lines is actually enough for a hurricane to get the lines caught on the tops of the towers.

post.title: Powerlines across massive lake show curvature of Earth

author.bio: My comments speak for themselves. Please feel free to read over them to learn of who I am. As anything typed here in this box is Questionable at best.
author.bio_html: My comments speak for themselves. Please feel free to read over them to learn of who I am. As anything typed here in this box is Questionable at best.

body:
Photo shopped. Along with most of the images in search. [Though the lake is wide enough to show the curvature](https://earthscience.stackexchange.com/questions/7283/how-high-must-one-be-for-the-curvature-of-the-earth-to-be-visible-to-the-eye), The towers look nothing like the ones in google map.  And none of the  towers are aligned as straight a the ones in the shopped photo.

https://www.google.com/maps/@30.0821945,-90.402867,2a,75y,28.81h,97.71t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1sRtJzjZMZl75e_JDL6Il7zw!2e0!6s%2F%2Fgeo0.ggpht.com%2Fcbk%3Fpanoid%3DRtJzjZMZl75e_JDL6Il7zw%26output%3Dthumbnail%26cb_client%3Dmaps_sv.tactile.gps%26thumb%3D2%26w%3D203%26h%3D100%26yaw%3D52.844273%26pitch%3D0%26thumbfov%3D100!7i13312!8i6656?hl=en-US
body_html:
Photo shopped. Along with most of the images in search. Though the lake is wide enough to show the curvature, The towers look nothing like the ones in google map. And none of the towers are aligned as straight a the ones in the shopped photo.

https://www.google.com/maps/@30.0821945,-90.402867,2a,75y,28.81h,97.71t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1sRtJzjZMZl75e_JDL6Il7zw!2e0!6s%2F%2Fgeo0.ggpht.com%2Fcbk%3Fpanoid%3DRtJzjZMZl75e_JDL6Il7zw%26output%3Dthumbnail%26cb_client%3Dmaps_sv.tactile.gps%26thumb%3D2%26w%3D203%26h%3D100%26yaw%3D52.844273%26pitch%3D0%26thumbfov%3D100!7i13312!8i6656?hl=en-US

body: They look the same to me, just way further apart. Perhaps the pictures where they're closer together were taken from far away and zoomed in. That'd be convenient if they were taken from land, and it would also show the curvature effect better. I know this is often done to make the sun and moon larger in a scene than they would actually appear.
body_html: They look the same to me, just way further apart. Perhaps the pictures where they're closer together were taken from far away and zoomed in. That'd be convenient if they were taken from land, and it would also show the curvature effect better. I know this is often done to make the sun and moon larger in a scene than they would actually appear.

parent.body: They look the same to me, just way further apart. Perhaps the pictures where they're closer together were taken from far away and zoomed in. That'd be convenient if they were taken from land, and it would also show the curvature effect better. I know this is often done to make the sun and moon larger in a scene than they would actually appear.
parent.body_html: They look the same to me, just way further apart. Perhaps the pictures where they're closer together were taken from far away and zoomed in. That'd be convenient if they were taken from land, and it would also show the curvature effect better. I know this is often done to make the sun and moon larger in a scene than they would actually appear.

post.title: Powerlines across massive lake show curvature of Earth

body:
I think that the picture does show the curvature of the Earth, but not necessarily in the way that people think.

Look at this picture:

![](https://i.imgur.com/dDlvhPS.png)

The bottom red line connects the first tower with the horizon. If you look closely you can see that the remaining towers don't follow the line, but rather bulge away from it. That is what you would expect if the surface was curved.

What people seem to be focusing on is the falloff of the towers on the right side of the picture. I suspect that this has more to do with optical distortion than it does with the Earth curving. Over 15 miles, the Earth curves about 10 feet, and the towers shrink away by much, much more than that.
body_html:
I think that the picture does show the curvature of the Earth, but not necessarily in the way that people think.

Look at this picture:

The bottom red line connects the first tower with the horizon. If you look closely you can see that the remaining towers don't follow the line, but rather bulge away from it. That is what you would expect if the surface was curved.

What people seem to be focusing on is the falloff of the towers on the right side of the picture. I suspect that this has more to do with optical distortion than it does with the Earth curving. Over 15 miles, the Earth curves about 10 feet, and the towers shrink away by much, much more than that.
